ok urm im not too sure if this is considered deemed to put in the study grp chat but someone please help.. is 0 a natural no or not..in a lecture video it said sequence is a(0) a(1) etc using a(n) where n is a natural number (suggesting that in this case 0 is natural??)but in our lecture  our teacher told us 0 is not a natural number. so someone help..
If you look at the syllabus doc  the list of symbols used does not have the set of natural numbers
They'll say positive integers  or nonnegative integers
This is because natural numbers is a contentious term and half of people thinks it should have 0 and another half doesn't
So u don't have to worry about that
At least not in national exams anyway
In school I think you just follow your teacher
Tbh it's quite bad practice to use the term natural numbers without defining it anyway
he was also confused with what hes saying
There's "positive integers" and "non negative integers"
hes like urm idk 0 shouldnt be natural but sometimes it is
If he confused then I also dunno what to do already
ehh I wouldn't be worried about it
generally use 0 unless qn states so we planning to do that
just ask him directly what natural numbers are defined to be
then just take what he says

Usually either(1) It does not matter OR(2) It is implied.If you are not sure  just use "the set of positive integers" or "the set of non-negative integers" where appropriate.For example  I am currently doing a measure theory module which always excludes 0. But my algebra professor loves to include 0 because 0 is the additive identity. So just look at what it implies.Just ask yourself one question: if I include 0  would it still make sense?Same goes with subset  ‚äÇ and ‚äÜ can mean the same thing.I have been dealing with this for years with no issue. So I don't think you will have a major issue.
This is a recent assignment that I did. Had the set of natural numbers include 0  it wouldn't make sense as we would have 1/0 (look at the way I defined E_(k n)).
